description: As a verb, from New Latin extrāvertō, from Classical Latin extrā- (“outside”) + vertō (“to turn”). As a noun and adjective, a back-formation from extraversion. Popularized in psychology by translations of German works by Carl Jung.

adjectives.description: extravert (comparative more extravert, superlative most extravert)

examples: The personality which thus combines introvert and extravert reactions... can be... called an ‘altrovert’...
An Extravert can hardly conceive the necessity which compels the Introvert to conquer the world by means of a system.

verbs.description: extravert (third-person singular simple present extraverts, present participle extraverting, simple past and past participle extraverted)

entries.meaning: Alternative spelling of extrovert, especially (early chemistry, obsolete) so as to be visible.
examples: It is not the moist air that extraverts any preexistent nitrous parts from the body of the minerals.
